I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) is extraordinarily vulnerable to climate 
change  due  to  its  (i)  high  socioeconomic  dependence  on  climate-sensitive  sectors  such  as 
agriculture and water, and (ii) low adaptive ability associated with widespread poverty and weak 
technical and institutional capacity. In 2008, the Government of the Lao PDR requested that the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) help draft a national strategy and action plan on climate change 
(NSAPCC) for the country. This proposed capacity development technical assistance (TA)1 seeks 
to  overcome  capacity  gaps  identified  in  the  NSAPCC  through  building  institutional  capacity, 
enhancing technical skills, and implementing pilot projects.   
 
2.  A reconnaissance mission took place in July 2009, and ADB circulated a draft TA concept 
paper for comment by the government ministries in October 2009. A consensus emerged on the 
need to strengthen the capacity of the eight technical working groups (TWGs) of the National 
Steering Committee on Climate Change, and to pilot various adaptation activities. A fact-finding 
mission with representation from the Nordic Development Fund followed from 26 to 29 October 
2009 to assess capacity needs of the TWGs, scope pilot activities, and discuss modalities of TA 
implementation. A memorandum of understanding was signed with the director general of the 
Environment  Department,  Water  Resources  and  Environment  Administration  (WREA)  on  30 
October 2009, agreeing to the core elements of the TA (impact, outcome, outputs, implementation, 
cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference of consultants). The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Although it has made steady progress toward achieving Millennium Development Goals, 
the Lao PDR—and its poorer communities in particular—are likely to suffer increasingly from 
climate change impacts, which risk reversing these past successes. The NSAPCC notes that the 
dry season is becoming longer, droughts are more frequent and severe, and the incidence of 
extreme flood events is increasing. Between 1966 and 2008, the country experienced about 30 
flood events, with one in 2008 causing a loss of $58 million. Strengthening climate resilience is 
thus central to the country’s sustainable development and poverty reduction agenda. 
 
4.  The  government  has  shown  a  strong  commitment  to  addressing  climate  change  by 
ratifying the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change in 1995 and the Kyoto 
Protocol  in  2003.  It  established  the  National  Climate  Change  Office,  the  National  Steering 
Committee on Climate Change, and eight TWGs in 2008. In May 2009, it published the National 
Adaptation Program of Action,2 which identified water, agriculture and forestry, and public health 
as high-priority, at-risk sectors due to climate change. It is preparing NSAPCC for approval in 
2010. The NSAPCC focuses on eight areas including (i) building awareness, (ii) strengthening 
policies  and  institutional  capacity,  (iii)  mainstreaming  climate  change,  (iv)  expanding  the 
knowledge  base,  (v)  building  adaptive  capacity,  (vi)  enhancing  ecosystem  resilience,  (vii) 
promoting comprehensive disaster management, and (viii) mitigating climate change. 
 
5.  However, translating climate change strategies, plans, and programs into concrete actions 
has been difficult due to constraints on human resources and institutional, technical, and financial 
capacities. The NSAPCC notes that climate change awareness is limited to a small circle of 
government staff members and that capacity to implement climate policies at the provincial level

in designated environmental management units is almost nonexistent. The October 2009 fact-
finding mission also confirmed that the capacity of the eight TWGs for implementing NSAPCC and 
for planning and budgeting for adaptation is limited.  
 
6.  The proposed TA will address these constraints by providing policy support to the National 
Climate Change Office and institutions responsible for each TWG3 to implement the NSAPCC 
effectively. It will also raise public and policy maker awareness on climate change and provide 
assistance for implementing pilot adaptation activities in water, agriculture, and forestry sectors. 
These  activities  will  also  reinforce  data  collection  systems  on  climate  change  impacts  and 
strengthen TWG capacity in data collection and analysis. 
 
7.  The proposed TA is aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy,4 which supports the 
government’s priority sectors under the Sixth National Socio-Economic Development Plan, 2006–
2010,5 with a focus on improving the national and sector-specific enabling environment for poverty 
reduction.  Besides  reforming  sector  governance,  building  sector  capacity,  and  ensuring 
sustainability,  the  strategy  includes  investment  in  infrastructure  projects  that  require 
mainstreaming of climate change concerns. The TA will also complement and strengthen links to 
other ADB projects6 in the Lao PDR. Further, the gap analysis carried out in the preparation of the 
ADB  climate  change  implementation  plan7 identified  a  need  for  increased  support  to  policy 
makers to take proactive roles in planning national and regional climate change programs. The TA 
will  support  integration  of  climate  change  considerations  into  development,  another  need 
identified as a priority activity in this plan.  
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  Impact. The TA’s main impact will be better climate-resilient development in the Lao PDR, 
leading to improved livelihoods, especially for vulnerable groups including women. The TA will 
take  a  holistic  view  of  adaptation,  including  strengthening  the  country’s  access  to  financial 
instruments available under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and 
the Kyoto Protocol, such as the Least Developed Countries Fund and Adaptation Fund.

9.  Outcome. The expected outcome of the TA will be an improved enabling environment to 
cope with climate change impacts. The TA will enhance the climate resilience of programs, plans, 
and/or policies by building institutional capacity for planning, budgeting, and implementing climate 
change actions; applying a learning-by-doing approach; and strengthening the information base 
for  decision  making,  such  as  through  economic  assessments  and  the  development  of 
methodologies for scaling up climate change actions. Capacity-building activities will be targeted 
at technical staff members and senior decision makers within the government. Pilot activities will 
allow the TA methodologies and outcomes to be replicated elsewhere and the TA benefits to be 
disseminated throughout the country. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The proposed TA will involve six outputs grouped under two components: (i) capacity 
development and technical support, and (ii) pilot adaptation activities in priority sectors.  
 
1.  Capacity Development and Technical Support 
11.  Assessment of investment and financial flows. To provide a sound economic basis for 
action, an assessment of investment and financial flows necessary to address climate change 
impacts will be undertaken in the water, agriculture, and energy sectors using methodological 
frameworks such as those being piloted by the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). 
The  assessment  will  serve  as  a  long-term  planning  tool  and  provide  input  to  budgeting  for 
adaptation as well as for raising additional financing from external sources. 
 
12.  Technical assistance and policy support to the technical working groups. As the 
TWG structure of the National Climate Change Office coordinates climate change adaptation and 
mitigation across multiple sectors and government bodies, the TA will engage the TWGs in 
developing  pragmatic  work  plans  to  realize  the  national  climate  change  strategy.  Training 
modules  on  planning  and  budgeting  for  adaptation  actions,  opportunities  for  maximizing  co-
benefits of these actions, and approaches for enhancing climate resilience of current and future 
investments will be drawn up. Further, since disaster risk management and climate change 
adaptation  intersect,  the  TWGs  will  also  be  encouraged  to  coordinate  closely  with  National 
Disaster Management Office at the Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare. Training activities will be 
conducted in cooperation with the World Bank, which provided initial support to TWGs, and other 
bilateral and multilateral donors such as the United Nations Development Programme. 
 
13.  Education,  training,  and  public  awareness-raising  campaign. The TA will include 
public awareness programs on climate change aimed specifically at youth, women, community 
leaders, and senior citizens. Training programs will target government personnel in both national 
and  provincial  environmental  management  units  to  build  skills  in  economics,  policy  making, 
planning,  and  budgeting  related  to  climate  change  through  learning-by-doing  activities,  staff 
exchanges, study tours, and participation in local and national training events and forums. This 
output will help government representatives to forge long-term relationships with climate change 
professionals  in  both  the  Lao  PDR  and  other  countries.  Moreover,  theme-specific  training 
programs  on  adaptation  in  selected  sectors  (e.g.,  water,  agriculture,  and  forestry)  will  be 
conducted to present guidelines and operational manuals to extension personnel to implement 
specific adaptation projects and to apply for international funds such as the Adaptation Fund.  
 
14.  Collaborative  mechanisms  for  information  dissemination  and  additional  pilot 
activities. This output, under the leadership of WREA, will include (i) disseminating lessons from 
the TA both nationally and internationally; (ii) supporting regional advisory and information-sharing

4   
bodies such as forums organized by the Mekong River Commission through its climate change 
adaptation initiative; and (iii) designing additional pilot activities to allow eventual scaling up and 
replication of the TA outcomes. The costs for implementing additional pilot activities will be 
estimated, and financing options will be identified to assist the government in their implementation 
following this TA’s closure.   
 
2.  Pilot Adaptation Activities in Priority Sectors 
15.  Pilot climate change adaptation activities in water, agriculture, and forestry sectors will be 
implemented on the basis of criteria such as the potential for scaling up, feasibility, alignment with 
national  strategies,  impacts  on  vulnerable  groups,  and  opportunities  for  poverty  reduction. 
Additional criteria may be developed in consultation with concerned ministries. The scope of each 
pilot activity will be determined on the basis of participatory rural appraisal and other bottom-up 
approaches. Impacts on adaptive capacity will also be monitored. 
 
16.  Water sector. Under the leadership of WREA, the proposed TA will pilot activities for 
coping with droughts in a northern province and floods in a southern province. The drought pilot 
activity will focus on improved water conservation using groundwater recharge and bioengineering. 
The flood pilot activity will center on climate proofing infrastructure, including changing the design 
of embankments, culverts, and irrigation and drainage channels. Both pilots will be implemented 
by provincial water resources and environment offices and will build on current ADB projects in 
these provinces. 
 
17.  Agriculture and forestry sectors. These pilot activities will use an ecosystem-based 
approach to climate change adaptation and include (i) climate proofing infrastructure, such as 
rural roads; (ii) integrating indigenous knowledge in local adaptation plans; and (iii) adopting 
stress-tolerant cropping systems and varieties, focusing on rice ecosystems. Activities featuring 
greenhouse  gas  mitigation  and  other  co-benefits  (e.g.,  air  quality,  health  improvement,  and 
employment generation) will be prioritized, including (i) biogas generation from farm waste; (ii) 
carbon sequestration through agroforestry, afforestation, and reforestation; and (iii) system of rice 
intensification to reduce energy use and methane emissions. Efforts will also be made to promote 
biogas as a commercially viable industry by expanding its use for cooking, lighting, and water 
pumping, which will reduce deforestation caused by fuelwood needs. The pilot activities will be 
implemented  by  the  provincial  agriculture  and  forestry  offices  in  close  cooperation  with  the 
Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF) and the National Agriculture and Forestry Research 
Institute. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the proposed TA is estimated at $3.4 million. It will be financed on a grant 
basis by Nordic Development Fund in the amount of €2.0 million (about $2.8 million) and ADB's 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF–IV) in the amount of $300,000. The government will 
provide $300,000 equivalent in-kind, through provision of counterpart staff members. The grant 
from the Nordic Development Fund will be administered by ADB and utilized on a front-loading 
basis. The cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The proposed TA will be implemented over 30 months from March 2010 to September 
2012 in close cooperation with the National Steering Committee on Climate Change and its TWGs. 
WREA will be the executing agency, and the National Steering Committee on Climate Change will

5
serve  as  the  TA  steering  committee.  The  implementing  agencies  will  be  the  line  ministries 
responsible for the target sectors, that is, MAF, the Ministry of Energy and Mines, and WREA. 
Other  line  ministries  and  agencies,  provincial  water  resources  and environment  offices,  and 
provincial agriculture and forestry offices will be involved through workshops and forums, direct 
consultations, and pilot implementation. The director general of the Department of Environment at 
WREA, as the project director, will monitor and guide implementation. WREA will keep ADB and 
the Nordic Development Fund informed of any significant deviations from the agreed project 
implementation  schedule.  Within  3  months  of  TA  completion,  WREA  will  submit  a  project 
completion report.  
 
20.  An international consulting firm will be recruited following quality- and cost-based selection 
(80:20) in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from 
time to time). The firm will provide 40 person-months of international and 90 person-months of 
national consulting services. The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
The TA team leader will be located at WREA, but consultants will also work in the agencies 
responsible  for  the  eight  TWGs  or  the  provincial  offices  (for  implementing  pilot  adaptation 
activities). Procurement and disbursement will be done in accordance with ADB's Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) and ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook.8 Upon completion of the TA, all procured assets will be turned over to WREA. Funds 
for office equipment, workshops, training seminars and conferences, and administrative support 
and reporting will be managed by WREA. Funds for pilot adaptation activities will be managed by 
the implementing agencies:9 WREA for water pilot activities and MAF for agriculture and forestry 
pilot activities. WREA and MAF will maintain separate accounts; have these accounts and related 
financial statements audited annually by an external auditor in accordance with auditing standards 
acceptable to ADB; and submit to ADB, within 6 months of the close of the fiscal year, certified 
copies of audited project accounts and financial statements and auditor's reports, all in English.  
 
21.  For  funds  to  be  expended  by  WREA  and  MAF,  an  advance  payment  facility will  be 
established at the Bank of Lao PDR. Its ceiling amount will be based on estimated expenditure on 
a quarterly basis based on agreed work plans, not exceeding $300,000. The account will be 
established,  managed,  replenished,  and  liquidated  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook and arrangements agreed upon by the government and ADB. 
The  statement  of  expenditures  procedure  will  be  used  to  reimburse  or  liquidate  eligible 
expenditures. Each individual payment reimbursed or liquidated using this procedure will not 
exceed $100,000 equivalent. Use of the Ministry of Finance's bidding documents for national 
shopping and competitive bidding is encouraged. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION AND DECISION 
22.  The  President  recommends  that  the  Board  approve  ADB  administering  a  portion  of 
technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,800,000 to the Government of the Lao 
People's Democratic Republic for Capacity Enhancement for Coping with Climate Change, to be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Nordic  Development  Fund.  If  the  Board  approves  ADB 
administering the technical assistance, the President, acting under the authority delegated by the 
Board, will approve ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000 on a 
grant basis, for Capacity Enhancement for Coping with Climate Change.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA), to be implemented over a period of 30 months from 
March  2010  to  September  2012,  will  strengthen  the  capacity  of  national  and  provincial 
government officials of the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) to cope with climate 
change. The TA will include (i) capacity development, and (ii) implementing pilot climate change 
adaptation activities in priority sectors. The consulting services will include international and 
national experts and undertake the tasks outlined herein. Both the team leader (international) 
and the deputy team leader (national) will be based at the Water Resources and Environment 
Agency  (WREA),  the  executing  agency  for  the  TA.  A  team  of  international  and  national 
consultants, to be provided by a consulting firm, will assist the team leader in coordinating the 
consulting inputs and facilitating efficient and effective use of resources. The consulting firm will 
be chosen on the basis of quality- and cost-based selection (80:20) in accordance with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time) of the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB).  A  full  technical  proposal  will  be  required  for  selection  of  the 
consulting firm. The inputs of the consultants are shown in Table A3.

B.  Scope of Services 
 
1.  Capacity Development and Technical Support 
 
2.  The  proposed  TA  will  be  implemented  in  a  fully  participatory  manner,  and  the 
consultants will hold regular consultation meetings with stakeholders. The consultants will 
undertake field visits and review, assess, compile, and/or collate data on current status and 
lessons and experience that can be drawn from ongoing climate change activities and ensure 
these are fully reflected in proposed TA activities. An inception workshop will be held in April 
2010, and the inception report will describe the preliminary findings and recommend revisions 
to the TA work plan and deliverables that are expected by the first midterm workshop (in 
October 2010).

Appendix 3  11 
3.  The consultants will carry out the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review  relevant  national  documents  such  as  the  National  Climate  Change 
Strategy  Action  Plan  and  National  Adaptation  Program  of  Action, 1  and 
information  on  agriculture,  energy,  waste  management,  and  water  resources 
policies. 
(ii)  Identify,  assess,  and  determine  investment  and  financial  flows  necessary  to 
address climate change in the agriculture, energy, and water sectors based on 
an internationally approved assessment methodology such as that used by the 
United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). 
(a)  Collect baseline data on agriculture, energy, and water issues relevant to 
the TA. 
(b)  Liaise  with  national  and  provincial  government  staff  members  and 
external  stakeholders  (e.g.,  nongovernment  organizations  and  other 
project consultants) to identify key issues for the agriculture, energy, and 
water sectors, including (1) trends and forecasts for demand and supply 
of agricultural produce, energy, and water; (2) proposed development of 
energy generation (especially hydropower), transmission and distribution 
network;  and  (3)  planned  development  of  irrigation  or  related  rural 
infrastructure,  urban  infrastructure,  and  infrastructure  related  to  waste 
generation and utilization. 
(c)  Prepare  working  papers  on  financial  needs  and  investment  flows 
necessary to address climate change in the agriculture, energy, and water 
sectors.  
(iii)  Identify and provide support to developing pragmatic work plans by the eight 
technical working groups in close coordination with the UNDP, World Bank, and 
other donors.  
(a)  Develop an institutional strengthening component for effective functioning 
of the technical working groups. 
(b)  Provide technical support in planning and budgeting of climate change 
adaptation in different sectors, opportunities to maximize co-benefits of 
climate  actions,  and  relevance  of climate  proofing  of  the  current  and 
future investments in the Lao PDR context. 
(iv)  Identify and assess capacity-building needs for climate change with a focus on 
national  and  provincial  policy  makers,  youth,  women,  senior  citizens,  and 
universities. 
(a)  Conduct interviews with decision makers and technical staff members in 
relevant line ministries and target provinces to understand the existing 
level of capacity in relation to climate change. 
(b)  Prioritize capacity-building needs of decision makers and technical staff 
members in relevant line ministries and target provinces to enable them to 
fulfill their assigned roles and to build long-term capacity. 
(c)  Develop  and  implement  a  community  awareness-raising  campaign  in 
relation  to  climate  change  risks,  adaptation  measures,  and  mitigation 
options, including use of public meetings, focus groups with community 
leaders, and newspaper and television and radio media exposure.

(v)  Organize national training events, staff exchanges, and study tours.  
(a)  Develop  and  implement  a  capacity-building  program  (including  a 
monitoring and evaluation framework) including workshops, learning-by-
doing training, study tours and exchange programs, and participation in 
national and international forums. 
(vi)  Conduct theme-specific training on adaptation in agriculture, energy, and water 
sectors;  prepare  necessary  guidebooks,  manuals,  and  reports;  and  make 
applications for international carbon markets. 
(vii)  Provide technical support to regional advisory and information-sharing bodies 
such as the Mekong River Commission for effective dissemination of TA results 
in various national, regional, and international forums.  
(viii)  Develop a plan for scaling up and replicating TA outcomes, in particular through 
government policies and programs, by designing and costing additional pilot 
activities  in  other  sectors,  and  identify  possible  arrangements  for  post-TA 
implementation.  
 
2.  Pilot Adaptation Activities in Priority Sectors 
4.  The consultants will assist WREA and the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF) in 
preparing, implementing, and monitoring selected pilot activities in high-priority sectors such as 
water,  agriculture,  and  forestry.  The  scope  of  each  pilot  activity  will  be  developed  in  full 
consultation with national and provincial government staff members and local communities, and 
their comments will be incorporated in the scope. 
  
5.  The consultants will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  Utilize the listed criteria (in para. 15 of the TA paper), and develop additional 
criteria, if necessary, for selection of pilot activities in the water, agriculture, and 
forestry sectors in close consultation with WREA and MAF. 
(a)  Review  and  synthesize  key  findings  on  climate  change  actions 
undertaken by national and provincial bodies.  
(b)  Identify critical factors for successful implementation of pilot projects. 
(c)  Identify mechanisms to enhance ongoing institutionalization of climate 
change actions at the provincial and national levels. 
(ii)  Prepare detailed design and implementation plans for pilot projects (utilizing the 
participatory  rural  appraisal  and  other  bottom-up  approaches,  and  also  by 
considering relevant gender dimensions), including budget and implementation 
arrangements, in close consultation with WREA and MAF. 
(iii)  Identify  and  assess  prospects  for  linking  pilot  activities  with  ADB-financed 
projects to enable mainstreaming of adaptation concerns. 
(iv)  Identify pilot activities that can benefit from the international adaptation funds. 
(a)  Identify  pilot  adaptation  activities  eligible  to  receive  benefits  from  the 
Least Developed Countries Fund, Adaptation Fund, and other funds; and 
prepare  scope  and  cost  estimates,  implementation  and  management 
frameworks, and a capacity-building plan. 
(v)  Identify indicators to be used to monitor the effectiveness of pilot adaptation 
activities. 
(vi)  Undertake  consultations  for  vetting  of  pilot  activity  design,  and  finalize  pilot 
activity design documents, including the implementation plan and stakeholder 
engagement plan.

Appendix 3  13 
(vii)  Coordinate the implementation of high-priority adaptation pilot activities in the 
water sector.  
(a)  Liaise with national and provincial government representatives, especially 
WREA and external stakeholders, to implement pilot activities in the water 
sector,  including  (but  not  limited  to)  climate  proofing  of  water 
infrastructure, water conservation, and integrated water management.  
(viii)  Coordinate the implementation of high-priority pilot adaptation activities in the 
agriculture and forestry sectors.  
(a)  Liaise with national and provincial government representatives, especially 
MAF and the National Agriculture and Forestry Research Institute, and 
other external stakeholders to implement pilot activities in the agriculture 
and  forestry  sectors,  including  climate  proofing  of  rural  infrastructure, 
integration  of  indigenous  knowledge  into  local  adaptation  plans,  farm 
insurance  schemes,  stress-tolerant  cropping  systems  and  varieties, 
biogas  generation  from  farm  waste,  carbon  sequestration  through 
agroforestry, afforestation and reforestation, reduction of energy use and 
methane emissions, and conversion of agricultural and forest residues 
into energy. 
 
6.  Land acquisition and involuntary resettlement will be avoided to the extent possible. In 
accordance  with  ADB's  Environment  Policy  (2002),  the  consultants  will  prepare  an  initial 
environmental examination and/or environmental impact assessment, if warranted, following 
ADB's Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003). The environmental assessments should 
identify  all  positive  and  negative  environmental  and  social  impacts.  The  consultants  will 
recommend measures (including changes in the design) to eliminate, offset, or reduce adverse 
impacts to an acceptable limit. Wherever feasible, the consultants will identify complementary 
works to enhance the positive environmental impacts of the proposed works. The costs and 
benefits of all such measures and complementary works will be estimated. 
 
7.  A draft environmental management plan will be prepared for each pilot activity to 
describe the procedures for environmental management and monitoring, including institutional 
arrangements; tasks and implementation schedules; estimated costs; reporting arrangements 
and schedules; and any special measures, such as training and public involvement activities. 
After  submission  of  the  draft  final  report,  a  workshop  will  be  held to  discuss  it  with  key 
stakeholders. The outcome of the workshop will be reflected in the final report. 
 
C.  Reporting 
8.  WREA will submit five technical reports to ADB and the Nordic Development Fund. The 
draft inception report will be submitted 2 weeks before the inception workshop (April 2010), and 
the final inception report will be submitted within 2 weeks after the inception workshop. The 
inception report will summarize initial findings and present an implementation plan to reflect 
specific, identified issues. The three progress reports, to be submitted after 8, 16, and 24 
months of mobilization, will be discussed at workshops and will present the interim results from 
the technical reports on capacity development and implementation arrangements for the pilot 
adaptation activities. The second and third progress reports will also discuss progress in 
implementing the pilot activities. The final report will be submitted 2 weeks after the final 
workshop. In addition, WREA, with support of the consultants, will prepare brief e-mailed 
monthly reports to ADB and the Nordic Development Fund on progress, delays, and issues.

reports,  technical  working  papers,  and  policy  briefings  to  enhance  capacity  of  targeted 
stakeholders. All reports, software, and data prepared for the TA will be provided in electronic 
form to WREA and ADB on completion of the services. 
 
10.  All  reports  will  be  prepared  in  English.  The  draft  final  report  will  be  submitted  in
